What you've heard is really very similar and very typical.
It's actually a syndrome that we're learning more about similar to post traumatic stress disorder.
PTSD is the diagnosis that is given after a war when veterans come home.
But it's been expanded to include those traumatic situations that people survive.
And in the case of families who've experienced the murder of a loved one, particularly for the younger children, we're finding the similarities.
Now, it's not always post-traumatic in the sense that veterans have come home for -from war and the war is over for them in a physical sense.
But many of these families, and particularly the siblings, are living with ongoing episodes of violence.
Right.

So we've got a lot to learn about the symptoms - the sleeplessness, the nightmares, the anxiety attacks, the constant replay of the episodes, the hyper fear, all of those are symptoms that we're seeing.
And what you've heard from Ms. Mohammed and the callers is very similar to what we've seen with other families.
Regrettably, murder is not the only crime that's in the human experience.
Is there something, though, different about murder as compared to armed robbery or even rape?
I think there are some differences.
Again, we have a lot more that we need to learn.
And in some ways, families that have experienced a suicide have a lot to teach in this situation.
But what's pretty clear about the situation with murder is the finality of it and the need for a family not just to heal but to figure out how to move forward without this person.

It leaves a hole and a gap.
And people are expected to go back to work within a week.
Siblings are expected to go back to school.
And the human service and health community has not adequately trained on how to provide the right services.
We really need the voices of these victims, really, the surviving family members to help us even know what to do and what's helpful.

The thing about this problem that we have in the United States, which is just pretty unique among industrialized countries, is that it does feed on itself.
There's a cycle to it.
And once you focus in on the violence and the fear that it breeds, you wind up seemingly and inadvertently creating more violence.
People stay in their homes and lock the doors, which creates isolated spaces in the community that are not thriving with life and people and are prime places for bad things to happen.
People start getting guns, thinking they're going to protect themselves.
And those guns often get used in crime and other episodes of violence.
It kind of feeds on itself on a very frightening way.
I wish we had some comparable television shows to ""CSI"" that really focused in on the prevention that we know works.
You know, maybe a murder prevention series or something.
I'm thinking, you know, we know that mentoring programs like Big Brother Big Sister really work.
We know that violence prevention education in schools for all children can reduce the number of fightings and violent episodes in the school.
We know that taking care of children at the infancy age really matters when it comes to school performance.
And so I wish we could turn our murder prevention activities toward the true prevention activities, because that's where we can stop this cycle.
Otherwise, we just continually feed on the violence, and it does continue to get worse.
